developers okay so the brackets are going to be in the right
place and the interfaces will not be starting with an i i I think that's the
differences right um so shot's fired anyway so we um spend more time reading
code than we do writing code um most of our tasks involve
reading code of some sort when we're adding features or fixing bugs when we're trying to understand a new system
that we might need to work on when we're doing code reviews when we're learning about new technologies and reading books
or blog posts or watching videos all of that involves reading code in fact developers on average spend
as much as 58% of their time comprehending existing source code that
is a quote based on Research from the book um the programmer's brain by Felina
hermans um I highly recommend this book I don't get a commission uh Felina
hermans is a a professor of Computer Science Education at F University
Amsterdam uh and she wrote this book called the programmer's brain with a subtitle what every programmer should
know about cognition so we spend more time reading
code than we do writing code but we don't practice reading code or we hardly
ever practice reading code explicitly and even if we do talk about
readability it's often about writing readable code so we're still not actually reading the code we're just
discussing what makes code more readable uh there's a lot of research in felin's book on that as well rather than books
that have lots of opinions on what makes um readable code that we won't mention so Felina is also a conference
speaker and she gave a talk in 2019 at strange Loop uh called how to teach
programming and other things that's literally her research domain and in this talk uh she mentions research from
1992 which is before I learned programming did anybody learn programming before or
1992 ah some of you okay cool um so anyway in 1992 there was some research
where they had a classroom of students who were learning programming Concepts they split the classroom into three
groups the first group would write and read code the second group would write
and read code but the code that they were reading actually had explanations about that code like what choices were
made why certain implementations were chosen Etc and the third group would only read that the code with those
explanations and what they found in this research was that actually the second and third group were better able to
reproduce the programming Concepts that they were learning over the first group that wrote code and read code without
explanations but we mostly learn programming by writing lots of code right and we still do
that um so after that talk someone came up to Felina and said but what if we did
practice reading code explicitly and that's how code reading club was born so they started an experimental
Club thinking how can we deliberately practice reading code the way that we practice writing code with code
catas um and I will share a link to my website at the end that has all of these
links for my slides uh Etc but do feel free to take pictures in the meantime um
so I heard I read about code Reading Club somewhere and I was like that sounds really cool I want to do that and
I got really lucky because a friend of mine actually reached out and said hey we're starting a code Reading Club do
you want to join I'm like yeah I do so we've been having a code reading club for about two years uh with monthly
sessions um not everyone is able to join every time some of us travel for work um
but we've been doing it for for two years and I found it really helpful and
that's why I want to share that experience with you um so in the code reading club we
take a printed sample of code of maybe one or two pages which is harder to find
than you might think a sample of code that's not too long but still has something going on and we apply
structured exercises to that uh code you can also do it electronically there's an
annotation tool that you can use but I actually prefer to do it on paper uh use some colored markers as adults we don't
get to play with colored markers enough so that's an added bonus um and and the screenshot that I have here is actually
the result of one of our sessions and I think that this is actually C from this
session but I'm not sure you can tell me better than I know um so just to give
you some examples of the exercises that we do we usually start with an exercise
called first glance that's literally what it is we take one minute we look at the code and we write down the first
thing that we notice about the code and why and that's already an interesting exercise because we have a very diverse
group of people people uh we all live in different countries England Netherlands Germany uh us even we work in different
roles from developer Advocate to uh developers testers quality coaches and
we all work with different languages Java C JavaScript Ruby um so we all have
really different experience um and we work in different industries of course so when we do the
first glance exercise it's really interesting in to see that different people notice completely different
things about a piece of code some people might say oh I noticed this and that's a familiar term so that gives me a hint of
what this is about someone else might say this syntax right here is completely
foreign to me I have no idea what's going on and I want to understand that before I try to make sense of the
rest uh next we might identify components and relationships between them in the code um which is interesting
if you're reading a foreign language or an unfamiliar language that you can still find the variables and the methods
Etc even if the syntax might be different um we also do an exercise
where we identify the five most important lines in this piece of code and that again is very interesting
especially if you don't agree upfront what most important means because different people will select completely
different lines uh someone might select these are the five lines that help me
understand what this code is about like a class name or a comment or a method name uh I mentioned we have testers and
quality coaches in our in our group they might notice these are the lines where you know decisions are made and I need
lots of test cases so these are the most important lines to me uh someone might say okay these five lines determine the
control flow through the code so those are the most important lines to me so if you do this exercise either see what
happens and what people think is most important and why or or see if you can agree with your group what most
important means because we me we found out over time that we actually ended up converging on most important lines so in
the beginning we had really different results and then over time as we had this club every month we ended up
agreeing on what most important uh lines were um we might identify Concepts that
the code deals with um and usually there would be people like I have no idea what
this means and there would always be someone in the group who can then explain that to the rest and it's always someone else so it's not like oh this
person knows way more than the other we're all learning from each other and then finally even though we
didn't maybe look at the meaning of the code and what it was about we'll take five minutes to summarize what we think
the code does to our best approximation and usually are able to um pretty well
describe what the code is actually about uh sometimes people would bring their own code code so that at least we could
explain at the end what the code was about sometimes we use code that we find on the internet um in which case it's
harder to be sure that you know what the code is about that's also not really the
point of the code Reading Club although I've also given code Reading Club
workshops at at conferences and meetups and there are always some people who really want to know what this code is
about despite like that's not the point of the exercise the point is to practice
is how we can get there but you know some of us really really need to know the answer
apparently um so again I really enjoy coding club and I really highly
recommend trying that out not just because it allows you to practice the skill of reading code and get better at
that uh but as I mentioned I really enjoy getting other people's
perspectives and learning how you know they see the same code completely differently or um I'm might ignore part
of the code AS oh that's not important to help me understand what it means and someone else might be completely fixated
on that like I need to know what that means and why that's really interesting to me um and finally as part of that
whole exercise you also have to make your own assumptions explicit so you're more aware of what you're thinking as
you're reading the code and that can also be helpful I wrote a blog post about that if you want to go read that
um but again I'll I'll share a link at the end uh the thing that I really really also
like about code reading club is that we are practicing reading code not to judge
the code but to understand the code so quick question who's ever looked at a
piece of code and thought this is utter garbage and the rest of you are too
afraid to put up your hands then or so Counterpoint who writes bad code
on purpose a few of us okay as a developer Advocate I write bad code so that I can
fix it but um most of us did not put our hand up so the next time you see a piece of code
and you think this is garbage whoever wrote that and that includes past you because I have seen
code that I wrote six months ago where I'm like apparently I learned a lot in six
months so now I can do a better job yay um we don't set out to re write bad code
so have a little bit of empathy for the circumstances under which the code was written we all know that we have
deadlines uh we might have had a bad night's sleep we might not understand the domain properly yet and we are
learning as we go so the code Reading Club also helps you practice a little bit of empathy
that I think we can use in the world today gestures broadly at everything um
so in fela's book she discusses reasons why code might be
confusing and she talks about a lack of knowledge a lack of information and a lack of processing power in the brain
these are tied to our cognitive processes so knowledge is the the
information that or the the knowledge that we have stored in our long-term memory the things that we know
short-term memory is the information that we have available to us right now and the working memory is how we process
all of that information a lack of knowledge might be either in the programming domain it
might be an unfamiliar language or syntax or programming constructs algorithms
design patterns that you're not familiar with or it might be in the business domain domain Concepts or business logic
that you don't know or don't know yet maybe you just switched to a different team a different industry a different
company and you need to learn all of these things we can deal with a lack of
knowledge of course by doing some research and Felina actually recommends that you make a list of the things that
you don't know so that you can also sort of keep track of your research because who's ever been like oh I don't know
what that means let me go find that out and then you go down a bunch of rabbit holes yes okay not just me um so you
know if you make a list of the things that you want to research you can keep yourself kind of on track um and if
there are things that you actually need to know a lot of the time then maybe memorize some of that information I know
that we can go look up the syntax of whatever or you know any information that we need if you need that a lot just
memorize it it's it's going to save you time a lack of information can be different things it can be unknown
details maybe the code is using a library method that you don't know the exact implementation of there could be
unfamiliar names especially if the the domain is for example new to you or a pattern that you're not familiar with
code can be connected in unknown ways that you might not find out until you run the test and something over there
breaks even though your Chang is over here so now you learn something about the system or there can be too many
things going on at once if you're processing lots of data and doing lots of transformations to it it might be
hard to keep track of everything that's going on in your brain we can deal with a lack of
information by chunking information together who's ever heard that you can keep seven plus or minus two things in
your shortterm memory okay some of you turns out it's actually less it's two to
six things so if you can group information together you can keep more
information in your um shortterm memory if you can recognize oh this is a pattern rather than all of the elements
separate elements that make up that pattern you can chunk it and keep more information in your shortterm memory so
learning Concepts and patterns is helpful a lack of processing power in
the brain can occur if there are too many processing steps or too many variables to keep track of and we can
deal with that by offloading some of that and using Memory aids for example a
dependency graph or a state table a dependency graph might look like this if you do it on a piece of paper so
you might Mark stuff and see how it's used throughout the code um this is an
example that I literally took from the code Reading Club website so for the person in the audience who's word
wondering where this code came from I have no idea I'm sorry um so this is a
way that we can create a dependency to help us visualize how the code um or how the control flow
Works um if you have lots of variables to keep track of we could use a state
table this is a very basic nested Loop in Java I'm sure it looks almost similar
in C um obviously this is a fairly trivial example I'm sure you have
examples in your code that are way more complicated but if you need to track the state of the variables a state table can
be helpful so Felina was writing another book uh
called code reading in practice unfortunately she put that on hold because she has too many great ideas

looking at different dimensions of code reading structure domain Concepts and
context so in terms of structure code is not read linearly we don't read it from
top to bottom we don't run it from top to bottom either in terms of domain the code deals
with behavior and data in terms of Concepts we've discussed we have programming Concepts
and domain Concepts and we have context the application doesn't exist in a
vacuum it has users it might talk to other applications there might have been a reason why we
created this application originally those reasons may have changed or no longer be valid so it helps to have a
little bit of context of why that application came to be and how it came to be because you can't capture all of
